comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
This Locomotive No. 1 is preserved in wonderful condition today and has pride of place inside the main entrance of the Powerhouse Museum Sydney.

Every kid, little and large, loves this engine.

At the display beside the engine there are a few photographs of the Loco being moved around Sydney streets for various ceremonial occasions - but I don't recall seeing this photograph there.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: That's great to know this steam engine is still here today, Bobmeade. Thanks.

comment.author: 36196524@N08
comment._content: It's an interesting location - tram tracks everywhere, and what appears to be an elevated tramway signal box and a rotating-disc tramway signal, above the couple in the centre.

comment.author: 27331537@N06

comment.author: 81028427@N04
comment._content: I believe thats the tram controllers hut at Railway Square behind Loco No 1

comment.author: 81028427@N04
86916510@N00
comment._content: But where was it being moved from? It wasn't new then from memory so it wasn't coming from the docks was it?

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: Just read Bob's explanation. It seems a lot of trouble to move it around by road. One would rely on very effective brakes on it's trailer when going down hill.

comment.author: 61804295@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] what a great find.. And it is interesting that Clydesdales were used to pull an engine and not a steam tractor that would of been plentiful on farms...
